title: rpcdaemon crashing when built with go 1.17
body:
#### System information

Erigon version: 2021.08.5-alpha

OS & Version: Linux

Commit hash : b1fef26767f2635da6816f0dc07acd3f3fa1e935

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
I suspect the crashes happen during the execution of a batch call, querying the chain state after a new block is received. I had two such crashes now, both happened in a few hours after upgrading to 2021.08.05. Previous version (2021.08.04) worked well.

EDIT: Erigon release version is irrelevant. Crashing occurs when rpcdaemon is compiled with go 1.17 (or 1.17.1). When compiled with go 1.16, rpcdaemon works well, without any issues.

#### Backtrace
[backtrace.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7077629/backtrace.txt)

I downgraded back to v2021.08.04 and I am still having the same rpcdaemon crashes. Not sure why this started happening today after the upgrade. I've been running erigon for more than a week and haven't had these crashes.
What is your go version?

error says `bad use of unsafe.Pointer? try -d=checkptr`. can you build rpcdaemon this way: 
```
go build -gcflags=all=-d=checkptr -o ./build/bin/rpcdaemon ./cmd/rpcdaemon
```
and then run as you usually do and show how it goes
what cli flags you use to run rpcdaemon?

> ```
> go build -gcflags=all=-d=checkptr -o ./build/bin/rpcdaemon ./cmd/rpcdaemon
> ```

Thanks for looking into it. I tried building rpcdaemon this way, here is the backtrace from recent crash.
[backtrace2.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7085189/backtrace2.txt)

I am on v2021.08.04 now. 

`go version `gives `go1.17 linux/amd64`

Flags: `--datadir=... --http.port=... --http.api=eth,web3,erigon,net,trace --ws`

I noticed previously attached trace (backtrace2.txt) still says `bad use of unsafe.Pointer? try -d=checkptr`. 

I rebuilt the executable again. I am attaching trace from another crash. This one now seems to have more info.
[backtrace3.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7086255/backtrace3.txt)

“  Not sure why this started happening today after the upgrade” maybe you was on go 1.16.*

i will dive into backtrace3 today. Not clear yet.

> “ Not sure why this started happening today after the upgrade” maybe you was on go 1.16.*

You may be on to something, I checked installation logs and  I was  on go 1.16 until recently. I'll try downgrading to 1.16 and see if that helps.

Would be great if you can add 2 more build flags and get one more logs (race detector may write to logs before crush) or trace: 
`GODEBUG=cgocheck=2 go build -race -gcflags=all=-d=checkptr -o ./build/bin/rpcdaemon ./cmd/rpcdaemon`
because I can't reproduce yet.

One (probably) non-related thing: I advise you go to 2021.08.05-alpha (because 08.04 has known problem when using --datadir option of rpcdaemon - there happening big performance regression - it start eating too much Disk - some people experienced 100x degradation). But unlikely it's reason of crush.

>  I advise you go to 2021.08.05-alpha

Yes, I already moved back to 2021.08.05.

> GODEBUG=cgocheck=2 go build -race -gcflags=all=-d=checkptr -o ./build/bin/rpcdaemon ./cmd/rpcdaemon

Using these build flags for the past 18hrs or so, the crashing bug simply  wouldn't show up :). Unfortunately these debug flags severely degrade performance, rpc queries are about 20x slower and cpu is full 100% all the time, so this may somehow affect the outcome. I did log two races, but they seemed benign, they didn't cause any crashing or other visible problems.

First one was about 30 secs after rpcdaemon startup:
[race1.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7096616/race1.txt)

Another is during shutdown:
[race2.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7096619/race2.txt)

For now I'll go back to release build to confirm it's still crashing and then try downgrading `go` to 1.16 to see if that helps.
this is great outcome

Glad to hear you found them useful. I missed one race, it seems distinct from the above two:
[race3.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7097668/race3.txt)
if added 2 fixes (for this 3 races): one is in new release v2021.09.01, but one i merged to devel after release.
I'll pull devel and let it run for a while.

> I'll pull devel and let it run for a while.

Unfortunately, that didn't help. It crashed three times since. I'll test downgrading go to 1.16 now. 

A quick description of the workload, maybe it helps finding the bug. There are several web-socket connections (about 7-8) to rpcdameon. One of these receives new block subscriptions. The other connections (after getting a new block) simultaneously each sends a batch of queries (reading chain state). I suspect crashing happens somewhere here.

@mdben1247 
Please try to add `-race` flag (alone it likely will not add much CPU load).

I found 1 change which may lead to dangling pointers (reason of crush): https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/pull/2564/files 
Here is the revert: https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/pull/2627

> Please try to add `-race` flag (alone it likely will not add much CPU load).

I'll try that next. Just to be sure, build like this?
`go build -race -o ./build/bin/rpcdaemon ./cmd/rpcdaemon`
Yes

rpcdaemon built with go 1.16 works flawlessly, no crashing at all.


Built with go 1.17 it crashes regularly. I am attaching new traces using `-race` flag, however there where no races detected.
[backtrace4.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7114319/backtrace4.txt)
[backtrace5.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7114320/backtrace5.txt)

Not sure how helpful those traces are. What has me a bit confused is there are `(bad use of unsafe.Pointer? try -d=checkptr)`suggestions in the traces, but `-race` build flag is supposed to imply `-d=checkptr` according to go [docs](https://golang.org/doc/go1.14). 

Any ideas on what else I can try to do to collect more data about the issue?
Maybe you can build old RPCDaemon? Let's say v2021.07.05 with go 1.17 and see if problem is still exists?

> Maybe you can build old RPCDaemon? Let's say v2021.07.05 with go 1.17 and see if problem is still exists?

I tried that, but couldn't make it work, this old version is missing some functionality that was added later (like batch ordering) and is critical to running the whole thing.

I also tried building `devel` with
`GODEBUG=cgocheck=2 go build -gcflags=all=-d=checkptr -o ./build/bin/rpcdaemon ./cmd/rpcdaemon`
without `-race` flag (then it runs reasonably well) and here is a backtrace of a crash, but not sure if there is any new info here.
[backtrace7.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7123112/backtrace7.txt)

Ok. Thank you for helping. 

Maybe it's not related to "race condition", maybe it's "wrong unsafe usage". 
Let's first understand - if it's related to "unsafe usage related to database" (because our db is written in C).
Here is the branch: `copy_db_val`

> Here is the branch: `copy_db_val`

This one is interesting, when it crashed it didn't say `bad use of unsafe.Pointer? try -d=checkptr`, but something else:
[backtrace8.txt](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/files/7127056/backtrace8.txt)
@mdben1247 hi. there is golang 1.17.1 released. Please try.

> hi. there is golang 1.17.1 released. Please try.

Still crashing.
No other people reported this issue. Maybe something specific for your server?

> No other people reported this issue. Maybe something specific for your server?

I'd say it's very unlikely. The server hardware has proven rock solid for past year or more, running under constant load 24/7, previously openethereum, now erigon (which also runs just awesomely on go 1.16). The more likely reason is we are running quite a workload, I suspect most people's erigon/rpcdaemon instances don't come near that stress level. That includes tx tracing, constantly querying various states, using batches, multiple ws connections etc.
ah, yes, we clearly know that on 1.16 you have no problem
